objective: count in hundreds and twenty-fives.
approach:
To begin this lesson, display an image of thousands of seats or people in a crowd and ask students how many seats there are altogether. Allow them time to discuss this question with their partners. Guide them to see that the seats should be grouped in a uniform way to help with counting. Ask students for their thoughts on how many seats should be allocated to each group, and ensure they have time to discuss the suitability of the numbers suggested and that they vocalise their reasons for rejecting/accepting the groupings suggested. Remind students that when we group numbers in tens, twenty-fives, fifties or hundreds, we need to count in steps of these numbers to get the total number given.
Use the counting stick or number line as a visual to rehearse counting in each multiple, and ensure that all students are counting. Discuss the similarities and differences of the images in Master. Count the totals together. Draw attention to the image of twenty-fives. Allow students time to discuss any patterns they propose, for example 4 twenty-fives in 100, 2 twenty-fives in 50, so 2 fifties in 100, and so on. Draw their attention to where the numbers are on the number lines.
Look at Master 3. With partners, allow students time to discuss the two methods. Remind them about the previous image of twenty-fives. Emphasise the importance of seeing numbers in many different ways.
During Guided Practice, students are counting in twenty-fives and hundreds, and completing number patterns.

objective: count in thousands, hundreds, tens and ones.
approach:

Then display a number represented by place-value counters and ask students what the number is and how they know. If necessary, allocate four selected students a role to act as either thousands, hundreds, tens or ones. They could state their place value and it would be the class' responsibility to recombine the number. Repeat this process using the numbers in Master, ensuring that you model the scribing of the number. Students should practise writing the numbers in numerals and words. Provide them with place-value counters if necessary. Students will practice dividing 1000 into 2, 4, 5 and 10 parts. This skill needs to be developed so it can be related to common scales and measuring equipment.

objective: understand and use place value to count.
approach:
To begin this lesson, recap on what students have learnt so far, and praise them for learning how to count in each group. Recap counting in twenty-fives, hundreds and thousands using the counting stick or number line, and then display the Explore task. Model counting each element incorrectly by assigning the incorrect number to each group, for example, hundreds to thousands and twenty-fives to tens. Allow students to talk through the process and point out the mistakes by asking them how they know at each stage. Have place-value counters and Base 10 materials ready so the students can use these in their explanations if necessary.
Emphasise that, although the image of the ones in Explore and Master 1 and 2 look different, they have the same value. Work through Master 3 and 4 with the class using models and images if necessary. Students may need extra time experimenting with concrete materials, place-value counters and place-value cards to fully understand the concept. Have place-value charts, place-value counters and counters/Base 10 materials ready so, if necessary, students can spend time partitioning and recombining numbers, generated either by rolling a dice four times or with numbers provided.
During Guided Practice, students are consolidating their understanding of place value. Allow a short time for feedback, especially for question 2. In question 3, students need to solve problems relating to addition of any single place-value part from the whole number.
End the lesson with a statement to set up learning for the next lesson. It could be a true or false statement such as 'zeros don't have any value'. This will facilitate discussion and allow students time to think about it.

objective: compare and order numbers.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them whose book has the greater number of pages. Allow them time to discuss and prompt them with probing questions such as: 'How do you know?' 'What makes you think that?' 'Can you convince me?' Model how to convince someone of their answer by using place-value materials as shown in Master. Draw attention to why and how we know that one number is bigger than the other by comparing each digit size. Repeat this for Master 2. Point out the different ways we can record our answers, e.g. using words and symbols. For example, '___ is greater than ____' or '____ >____'.
Allow students to discuss Master 3 in pairs using the same process modelled by the teacher. It would be useful to have Base 10 materials and place-value charts on the tables, so students can use them as needed. Then take some feedback, ensuring that students use appropriate vocabulary when discussing the relative size of numbers. For example, '___ is greater than ____' or '____ is more than ____' or '____ is the smallest' or '____ is the greatest'.
During Guided Practice, students are comparing and ordering numbers. It would be useful to display a talking frame on the board to ensure that students have good discussions. Use sentence starters such as: 'I know it is greater than… because…'; 'The hundreds/tens/ones digit shows me that…'; 'Convince me that…'; 'This picture proves that…'
Take feedback and generate the success criteria before students start working independently on the worksheet.

objective: compare and order 4-digit numbers.
approach:
To begin this lesson, display the three journeys from the Explore task without their distances and ask students to compare them. Use probing questions such as which distance is the shortest/longest? Allow them time to discuss and then take their feedback, always asking 'how they know'. Draw out of the students that they require some numerical measurements to be able to compare accurately, and remind them of the success criteria for comparing numbers that was drawn up in the previous lesson. Display the measurements and ask which distance is the shortest/longest. Discuss what is different about these numbers compared to numbers in the previous lessons. If necessary, add another step into the success criteria.
Work through the visual images in Master 1 to check that the class comparisons were correct, using the appropriate vocabulary and mathematical symbols. Model marking the numbers on a number line and ask how this demonstrates how to compare numbers. Allow students time to discuss and take feedback. Ask them how we can find the shortest distance; do we need to compare all three? Repeat the same process asking students for feedback while working through Master 2. students can work in pairs to complete Master 3, which provides the teacher with an opportunity to circulate and listen to the discussions.

objective: count in sixes, sevens and nines.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Allow time for discussion and listen to students' ideas, guiding them to draw on knowledge from previous lessons. objective: add using mental strategies (making tens, hundreds and thousands).
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them if the methods they have been using are appropriate for this type of calculation. Why, or why not? Ask students what they notice about the numbers and whether they know any strategies that might be helpful. Allow them time to work through the Explore task. Discuss how it is much easier to make multiples of 10, and then add if we are calculating mentally.
Show the class Master 1. It may be beneficial to practise a number of 'making 10' calculations before moving on, e.g. 2046 + 4 and 3241 + 9. Allow students time to practise this on whiteboards with their partners. Move onto the next step and allow them time to discuss what is happening in the calculation. Then model the process step-by-step for them.
Show the class how to 'make 100' as in Master 2. Allow them to practise making 100 with different calculations, for example, 93 + 4507, 1208 + 92, 2235 + 95, and so on. objective: subtract a fraction from a mixed number.
approach:
To begin this lesson, remind students of previous learning on subtracting fractions and ask them to discuss this with their partners. Then show them the Explore task. What is the problem asking us to do? What do we already know? What operation do you think we need to perform? Allow them time to work on this.
Work through Method 1, thinking out loud, to show the class the calculation. We know we have 1 1/5 l of water and we want to remove 2/5 l. The easiest way to calculate this is to change 1 1/5 l into fifths. So, 1 whole = 5/5. Add that to 1/5 and we get 6/5 which is equivalent to 1 1/5. Now we can easily calculate 6/5 – 2/5 to get 4/5. Is the fraction in its simplest form? Is there another way to calculate the answer to the problem? Give students time to discuss this with their partners, and then invite volunteers to share their ideas with the class.
If no one demonstrates the method in Method 2, work through the process thinking out loud: We can partition 1 1/5 into 1 whole and 1/5. We can subtract 2/5 from 1 whole because we know that 5/5 = 1, so 1 – 2/5 = 5/5 – 2/5 = 3/5. Then we can add on the remaining 1/5 to give us 4/5.
Display Master 2 and model the process thinking aloud: Oak starts with 1 1/5 l of water. She uses 2/5 l so the amount of water will decrease. How can I show that?
During Guided Practice, students are subtracting fractions from mixed numbers. Ask them to practise all methods.

objective: solve word problems involving fractions.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and read the problem to them. What do we know? What do we want to find out? What is the length of Tama's fishing trace? Allow students time to work on this with their partners. Suggest your friend thought drawing a fraction bar would be helpful. Display Master, thinking out loud to model. Draw a bar representing 3 m and mark each metre so that the bar is divided into 3 parts. How many parts should we break each metre into? Why? Tama cuts the fishing trace at every 3/4 of a metre. Mark every 3/4. How many pieces of fishing trace do we get? Model counting each piece. How can we explain what I just did using quarters in my explanation? Allow students time to discuss this in pairs and encourage them to give feedback such as: We know that 1 m = 4 quarters, and therefore, 6 m must be equivalent to 24 quarters because 4 × 6 = 24. There are 8 3 quarters in 6 m, so Tama can cut eight 3/4 m pieces of fishing trace.
Provide students with another question and give them time to try solving it with their partners on whiteboards. Take feedback about challenges and successes.

objective: convert years to months and weeks to days.
approach:

Display Master 1. If we know 1 year = 12 months, then how can we calculate 8 years in months? How many groups of 12 are there in 8 years? Ask students to discuss this in pairs and then feed back to the class. Invite a volunteer to show how to calculate this. Do the same for Master 2.
Display Master 3. In pairs, ask students to talk about the best way to calculate 14 years in months. Point out that we can use a number bond to break 14 into 10 and 4. Explain that 10 × 12 = 120 months. What about 4 × 12? We know 4 x 12 = 48. What statements can you make about the lengths of time now we have converted all the years to months? Display Master 4. What units of time are we measuring in now? Which key fact would help us with our conversions (1 week = 7 days)? Show the class how to calculate this. Do the same for Master 5.
